Starting a call center is not a cheap investment. The cost will vary dependent on the location of your business - but the equipment and general cost of starting a call center is never cheap. Even before getting to work out the logistics, a company will have to obey the guidelines and regulations for that particular location. Once the paperwork complies with the requirements. To start a call center you will need to: Have a strategic business plan - Having objectives will allow you to shape the kind of call center you want to establish. A business plan will prepare you for potential growth and expansion. As well as this, the expenses need to be managed. Having this plan gives the company a guideline to follow to ensure sustainability. Identify the purpose of your call center - The most common being either inbound or an outbound call center. Or maybe the less popular telemarketing. Is it going to be based on sales, customer service or informative support? It may be a mixture of all of them. Choose a suitable location - There are many factors to consider. If you need multilingual employees, maybe situating the call center in a big city will give you the skilled people you need. If you are proving a local service, a smaller town will be more appropriate. The distance from headquarters is vital. Not only does it build brand awareness, but if there is a problem, it makes it easier to help solve the situation. There are many other factors, such as the budget that needs to be considered. As experts say the three most important things in marketing are Location, Location, Location. Have the appropriate equipment and software tools - The physical equipment of headsets, monitors and laptops are needed. You'll also need a phone system, CRM software and a stable internet connection. All tools need to be durable and reliable. A slow call center will quickly fail; quality is a must. Good luck!

The call center business in India has been expanded for the last few years. There are two types of Call centers in India: Inbound Call Centers ( A Place where business calls are received from the prospective customers)Outbound Call Centers (A Place where business calls are made to the prospective customers)Call centers play a vital role in a company. Not only a sales perspective but also it helps companies to establish their customer relationship. If you want to start your Call center, Following steps will help you to start your own: 1. First of all, You need to have a business process so that you can decide which call center you have to setup. Like if you are running a third-party business, You will be required to start an outbound call center process, but if you're some kind of manufacturing or customer service, You will need an inbound process. Likewise, if your business is to process paperwork, Non-voice/data processing call center will be required to be set up here. 2. To start a call center, first, you have to prepare the requirements such as computer systems, Vonage, Toll-free numbers, etc. If your business process is service-based and you want your customers to directly pay through your sales team, the Payment gateway will be required there. 3. Prepare an RFI and RFP. Get a technical team to install the systems in place. Please identify the most feasible phones, lines, and other systems as this will be an irreversible capital investment. Cisco and Avayas are the widest phones in India. Desktops may be average. Try having a good solid NOC and IT Infrastructure team. Their main function will be to ensure 100% up time of links and servers at ALL TIMES. We do not want instances of applications going down and calls being queued up with no-one to help the customers out. 4. Prepare the necessary policies and procedures in your workplace. Make sure you've listed every process like call flows, SOPs, inter-Intra department communication channels, etc. You should have a robust, simple, and easy-to-follow process laid down for your customers. 5. If you're into the inbound process, prepare a proper estimate for the amount of inbound traffic you're expecting. Hire workforce staff first and then go to hire operational staff. These steps are just an overview. If you want an experienced consultant for starting your call center, You can contact through this phone number +91-9821399320.

It really depends on the area you focus on, whether you want to establish a smaller or bigger call center, if your call center should be placed in one location or your employees will work remotely. As I don't have this information, my suggestions will be a little bit more general.  First of all, it is important to ask the following questions: Job description and tasks - Do I really need the call center? What tasks do I have for them? Is it enough of work or can I delegate it to another department in my business?Budget - What is my budget for call center? Is it enough for all the salaries? What will be my costs connected to call center - for equipment needed or call center software + call credit?Employees - Where can I find the right people? How will I train them to provide excellent service? What structure do I want to have in my call center?Once you go through these questions, these are the most important steps: #1 Find the right people and educate them continuously & give them regular feedback #2 Decide whether you want to have an on-premise office or run a virtual call center (call agents are working from different locations). #3 Choose the right call center software based on your budget #4 Buy equipment needed - PCs, hardware phones or headphones, etc. I perceive crucial to choose the right call center software I prefer the ones which are cloud-based, as they provide you with much bigger flexibility, your employees can work from any location and you can always access your call center data from anywhere. So here are a few suggestions on how to choose the right call center software: Make initial research of the best call center providers on the market - you can use for those different directories like G2crowd, Capterra or GetApp. These are top provides on the market in my opinion: CloudTalk (Capterra rating - 4.8/5) - $15/per month/per user RingCentral (Capterra rating - 4.2/5) - Contact vendor JustCall (Capterra rating - 4.1/5) - $25/user/month Aircall (Capterra rating - 4.2/5) - $25/user/month (min 3 users) 2. Set your priorities and expectation from the right call center software Have a look at the features you’ve been using most frequently. Figure out what are the most important ones for your team and treat these as a priority. 3. Test the solution Most software providers offer free trial periods, usually for more or less two weeks. This way, you can see if the app works smoothly, which features are included and whether you actually enjoy using it.

Since you have decided what kind of business you want to run, then, you should run a feasibility study to determine if it will make you any money and which niche will you be targeting. Then, you need to build your business plan which will include your marketing and digital plans. Here is what I tell my clients: Plan what you want to do and then do it. First pick something that you would like to sell. It can be anything to start. Keep it legal, socially acceptable, and fun for you. Then run a feasibility study on it. You can get help for free online. If your study says don’t do it, then don’t do it, find something else. Repeat. When you find something that appears to have a demand, then put together your business plan. So, you want to start a business, any business, anywhere. Or, you want to introduce a new marketing channel. Or, you want to modify your marketing plan Start by deciding what business you want to conduct. Use a feasibility study to help do this. Then create a business plan that contains your marketing plan which in turn has your web presence plan. You will be required to determine the effectiveness of your plan as you put it together. Let me quote Benjamin Franklin: “By failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail.” Once you have the business plan completed, you will have a road map for where you want to go and the milestones along the way so that you can measure your progress and to make sure that you stay on course. Your business plan will have the results of your research and budgeting. Your research phase will help you find out what rules you will need to follow in whatever geographic area that you want to headquarter. Budgeting is one of the least prepared for part of your plan, so look at it hard. You really need to make sure that you cover your resources and marketing efforts thoroughly. And, take a hard look at crisis management as well. If you don’t have a clue on how to build the business plan, I suggest you hire a business consultant. With their help you will get a marketing consultant and me (maybe) as your web presence consultant. You don’t have to hire anybody if you are inclined to do it yourself. Search online for business plans. You’ll get all sorts of templates and some help on how and why to use them. I recommend Sean Castrina, he has outlined a plan that you can download for free. I’d like to quote Sean Castrina here: “The mere exercise and discipline required to write a business plan separates those who think they want to be an entrepreneur from those who will be an entrepreneur.”

Your strategy depends on the purpose. Is this to support your product or service? Or do you want to be an outsourced service provider? Either way, there are a few universal minimum basic fundamentals: Facility: Unless your going to use a virtual workforce or work at home model, you’re going to need space. You’ll want to be strategic in site selection and balance cost against being located close to your ideal workforce demographic and accessibility. People: You’ll need to create an ideal employee profile of what skills are needed, and a plan for recruitment and training of staff and leadership personnel. Technology/Infrastructure: You’ll want workstations and high bandwidth network capabilities along with an ACD platform to support contact management. You’ll need a CRM system to manage transactions for your customer base. Process: You’ll need to have mapped out your contact flow, recommended scripts or verbiage, call handling procedures as well as department policies. You’ll also want to have goals and expectations communicated well along with roles and responsibilities. In addition you’ll need to be prepared to handle forecasting, scheduling, reporting, along with quality assurance to ensure optimal performance management. Very tip of the iceberg stuff but these are minimal essentials to getting off the ground.
